item.title: Mastering Pelvic Window
item.content:encoded:
↑ you want to look on the L side of the bladder for the fluid. Posterior to the bladder (R side of image) is the prostate/sem ves, not where free fluid will be.


Fluid will appear first in post cul-de-sac on supine pt


↑ This is a very subtle fluid collection. Only visible bc bladder acts as a window. An empty bladder is indeterminate.



↑ small amnt of fluid


↑ arrow points to bladder b/c you can see the bladder wall. Left of the bladder is partially anechoic blood and echogenic blood


↑ retroflexed uterus with free fluid


Small amnt of free fluid in young female could be physiologic


↑ This a cyst, free fluid would not be spherical

item.title: Mastering Perisplenic Window
item.content:encoded:
↑ Don't angle too anterior or you'll get stomach instead of kidney. To get kidney, keep probe more parallel to the bed.


↑ When it's angled upward too much, you lose the kidney and get the stomach which looks odd


Inspiration generally leads to worse views as air enters the field.




↑ Subcapsular hematoma and hemoperitoneum

Enlarged left liver lobe can resemble subcapsular hematoma



↑ With flow you can see it's liver and not free fluid


↑ Ascites and enlarged L liver lobe


↑ Small hemoperitoneum and also spleen has parenchymal damage and appears heterogenous


↑ Hemothorax and hemoperitoneum

↑ only hemothorax


Images

↑ parenchymal injury and small free fluid at 11 oclock


Spleen has hyperechoic regions that is evidence of parenchymal injury


↑ Retroperitoneal fluid

↑ Hemoperitoneum and hemothorax


arrow is a small amount of fluid, heterogenous hyperechoic spleen represents splenic laceration grade 3/4

item.title: Mastering Perihepatic Window
item.content:encoded:
↑ This is gallbladder, not +FAST


This could be confused with fluid, but as the liver slides with insipration the shape and density of the collection doesn't change, so it's not a liquid.



↑ Liver injury appears hyperechoic

↑ This fluid collection is retroperitoneal from a renal laceration. Pointer indicates the true renal capsule, fluid is around the renal capsule.


↑ This is not a +FAST, this is the gallbladder. We don't see the kidney bc we aren't at the normal perihepatic window. The anechoic fluid has a subtle wall around it containing it and doesn't extend upward like blood would.


↑ Here if you look closely the fluid is below the perinephric fat so it is retroperitoneal.


↑ Some fluid is anechoic and some is echogenic, so could be clotted blood or also bowel. We can see the fluid abuts right against the liver with no subtle bowel wall separating them so we know it is free fluid.

↑ The points indicates a shine-down artifact which is, in fact, free air in the abdomen.


No fluid in morrison pouch, but that circle of fluid is sus. Fluid doesn't extend around kidney or anywhere else and has a small wall - it is bowel.


↑ This is retroperitoneal

↑ This is peritoneal as it is between perinephric fat and the liver

item.title: Mastering PSL View
item.content:encoded:
↑ This is a pericardial effusion because it extends from the apex of the heart to beyond the descending Aorta.

↑ This is L pleural effusion


Here the subcostal view was unclear whether it was a percardial effusion or fat pad. But on PSL window the questionable effusion is only present anterior to the heart in the supine pt, so it is very likely a fat pad.

item.title: E-FAST
item.content:encoded:
Don't miss hemopericaridum bc you're expecting an anechoic appearance. Hemopericardium can be echogenic.


↑ this pt was stabbed 15mins PTA, fluid is not anechoic

item.title: Lung US
item.content:encoded:
If you see A-lines and lung sliding, this signifies an absence of interstitial syndrome, alverolar consolidation, and pleural effusion at that specific area.

  • True B lines go all the way to the bottom of the screen.
  • B lines can be indicative of PNA, pulmonary contusion, pulm fibrosis, pulm infection
  • B lines on both sides indicates diffuse process like pulmonary edema

C profile is tissue/hepatization appear of lungs.



DLP is when a PTX is so small you can see a non-mobile segment of the pleura between two moving segments


Effusions can be anechoic or echogenic. Echogenic effusions are associated w hemorrhage, CA, infection

item.title: Aorta Ultrasound
item.content:encoded:
Common reason for difficulty in overlying bowel gas. Use gentle transducer pressure to displace bowel gas.

Aorta is not a straight line, will need to 'rock & glide' to visualize who aorta all the way down.

Beware you do not slide from the aorta to the IVC without realizing it

Identify the celiac and SMA to ensure this is the Aorta

90% of aortic aneurysms are near the renal arteries or lower.

  • As you proceed down, the Aorta becomes more superficial.
  • Follow the aorta through the bifurcation into common iliacs which occurs are the umbilicus
  • The common iliacs will then dive deeper/more posteriorly.


If you tilt to a more coronal view, you can see both common iliacs.


You want to measure at B which is the widest part of the aorta






↑ If your field of depth is too shallow, you may mistake the two vessel on the top for the IVC and aorta, but those are actually SMA and SMV. You need to visualize the vertebral bodies to have a frame of refence to know the Aorta should be right on top of the vertebral bodies.


↑ These images have athersclerotic plaques and intimal thickening but not aneurysm



Left side has large mural thrombus, R side does not


Fusiform aneurysm has gradual widening of the aorta like a slope/cone.


Saccular aneurysm is more aprupt dilatation.


90% of AAAs are infrarenal


This thin speck of fluid next to contained kidney cyst is retroperitoneal hemorrhage from rupture


↑ Those little stripes of free fluid adjacent to Morrison's pouch is retroperitoneal hemorrhage.




↑ Reverberation artifact, not a dissection

item.title: Gallbladder US
item.content:encoded:
Decision for operative management of cholecystitis is made only after CBD is evaluated because we need to r/o choledocolithiasis. Must obtain a formal US or be proficient enough to evaluate the CBD on US.

If you can't visualize GB, try having pt take deep breath. With inspiration on sagittal view, liver/GB will come into view from the L side.
Also try L lateral decubitus position


Whether or not the stones are mobile and roll around in the GB will tell us whether the stone is impacted or not.



Gallstones can be trapped in the folds


Septations are rare


Shape should be tapering like a sweet potato/carrot, not rounded at the neck like an eggplant. We must visualize the neck of the GB.


↑ Reverberation artifacts, not to be confused with pathology


Here, there are mustiple stones with clear echogenic shadowing. There is some sludge on top of the stones here.


3 stones here, with one in the neck and impacted. The impacted one did not move around in the lumen of the gallbladder.


↑ There are several stones here, but the leftmost is too small to cause acoustic shadowing, less than ~3mm.


↑ Harmonics can help visualize stones and shadowing


Clinical significance of sludge is unclear. Sludge is isoechocic to liver parenchyma.





Measure anterior wall


↑ This pt has wall thickening that was nonbiliary, was from CA, proteinemia, sepsis


↑ GB wall thickening due to liver disease



Focal wall thickening without cholesterol crystals warrants further examination


↑ Small fluid collection at 9 o'clock


Fundus is most common site for cholecystitis perforation due to less blood supply


7mm innerwall-to-innerwall
Some say add 1mm per decade of life >70yo




↑ Choledocolithiasis

↑ Stone in CBD and stones in GB. CBD not dilated but can obviously see gallstone


GB, and CBD right below in Sag view

Summary

item.title: Renal/Bladder US
item.content:encoded:
Note that we need to view the pelvis, for example, cross-section A and C would not include the pelvis to assess for hydronephrosis. Sweep through the kidney




If there is difficulty viewing the renal pelvis, pt can be placed in right lat decubitus to get a better view

Hydronephrosis



Chronic hydronephrosis will lead to thinning of the parenchyma.

Hallmark of severe nephrosis is the connection of the major with the minor calyxes and pelvis.
Renal fluid should be anechoic. If there are echos in the fluid, assume it's blood/pus.

It's easy to miss mild hydronephrosis.
Don't set the gain too high or it could bleed over and obscure the hydro. Use color dopper to see if fluid is blood vessels or urine.

If there is extra-renal pelvis dilation, that's okay as long as intrarenal pelvis is not dilated.












balloon inflated in prostatic urethra

Stones

Bladder

item.title: Ovarian Torsion
item.content:encoded:
Power doppler is not directional, just based on amplitude of flow and is perhaps more sensitive


This shows flow but the flow is short and staccato which means it's poor flow. This was a partial torsion in the OR
